system_overview: Ethical Identity Cards applying Bartle taxonomy to ethics practitioners, helping them identify their position within organizational games and choose tactics appropriate to their constraints.

mindsets_paradigms.current: Ethics = individual conscience; practitioners as solo heroes
mindsets_paradigms.target: Ethics = strategic positioning within organizational game
mindsets_paradigms.intervention: Make the game visible; identity as tactical choice

organizing_principles.intervention: Cards provide vocabulary for collective strategy

information_flows.current: Role identifications private; no collective mapping
information_flows.target: Network visibility: 'we have too many Achievers'

dynamic_processes.embedded_values: Organizations value individual contributions; collective action suspect

social_positionalities.power_dynamics: Senior staff can take risks; junior employees must conform
social_positionalities.safety_concerns: Some can be 'Killers' (disrupters); others risk career
social_positionalities.legitimized_expertise: Game design framing legitimizes tactical thinking about ethics

invisible_work.articulation_labor: Wong's research documents the 'soft resistance' practitioners do
invisible_work.emotional_labor: Managing cognitive dissonance between values and constraints
invisible_work.unrecognized_labor: Quiet resource redirection, project delays, coalition building

embedded_systems.policies: HR policies may constrain collective action
embedded_systems.economic_logics: Ethics practitioner as individual hero serves corporate interests

achiever.description: Driven by measurable outcomes and visible wins
achiever.risks: May sacrifice depth for metrics; feeds corporate capture

explorer.description: Investigates systems, finds hidden problems, maps territory
explorer.risks: May never move from research to action; analysis paralysis

socializer.description: Builds relationships and coalitions; values connection
socializer.risks: May prioritize harmony over confrontation; avoid hard truths

killer.description: Disrupts harmful systems; willing to create conflict
killer.risks: Career-ending moves; requires accumulated capital or exit plan

integrated_intervention_strategies.infrastructure_work: Make organizational game visible; provide tactical vocabulary; identity as choice

integrated_intervention_strategies.intervention: Workshop activity: map collective role composition
integrated_intervention_strategies.infrastructure_work: Participants map who plays which role; identify gaps and coalitions
Level 2: actual org chart + role mapping; identify strategic positions

invisible_trail: TILTH investigation embedded showing project failure
Decision to use Bartle taxonomy (from game design)

meta_rule: Analyze practitioner positions by asking: What role in the organizational game does each person occupy, AND what infrastructural conditions (job security, performance metrics, career trajectories) constrain which tactics are available from each position?
